feed.title: NewsTracker: apple
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Apple Pay launches in Britain, with hiccups
entry.summary:
Users first load their credit and debit card details into an app on their Apple phones or watches.

The last hold-out, Barclays, confirmed on Tuesday its debit card users and Barclaycard credit card customers will be able to use Apple Pay in the future.

entry.title: Why Apple Music is worth every cent
entry.summary: MANY have scoffed at Apple's decision to offer a music streaming service that charges $11.99 when its closest competitor, Spotify, offers an all-important, advert-supported free option.

entry.title: Apple Music promises revolution, but traditional DJs are what set it apart
entry.summary:
Real-time radio, of all things, is what truly distinguishes the newest and splashiest streaming service, Apple Music.

Apple has about 30 million songs to stream at your request.

Complete with high-profile DJs and programmed shows, it sets the service apart from the pack and best illustrates Apple's ambition - to become a destination spot not unlike media giants of yore.

And Apple Music pulls in whatever songs you've purchased from iTunes in a fairly intuitive way.

entry.title: 5 things for Apple (and you) to keep in mind as Apple Music is launched
entry.summary:
Apple can make people spend $700 on a phone without blinking, but can it get a critical mass to pay another $10 a month?

With just one recent op-ed, Taylor Swift reset the whole argument about Apple's planned free three-month subscription (or, as artists see it, a quarter of a year without royalty payments).

entry.title: FTC exploring Apple rules for streaming music rivals in App Store
entry.summary:
Apple takes a 30 percent cut of all in-app purchases for digital goods, such as music streaming subscriptions and games, sold on its platform.

Apple has long been a leader in digital music through its iTunes Store, but it has been a relatively late entrant to on-demand streaming.

entry.title: FTC exploring Apple rules for streaming music rivals in App Store
entry.summary: Streaming services' chief grievances with Apple stem from the company's 30 percent cut.

entry.title: Apple Music: Everything You Need to Know
entry.summary: The default screen shows the newest of the new from all genres each week, as picked by Apple's editors.

entry.title: China fears propel Apple shares toward five-day losing streak
China fears propel Apple shares toward five-day losing streak
entry.summary: Also rattling investors was a report this week by research firm Slice Intelligence that sales of the Apple Watch have dropped since its launch in April.

entry.title: Judge voids $532M award in iTunes infringement case
entry.summary:
Apple had argued that the damages were too high because jurors might have improperly considered the entire market value of the products, rather than distinguishing between patented and unpatented features.

The lawsuit said Patrick Racz, a co-inventor of Smartflash's patents, had discussed some of his ideas in 2000 with officials of a European company, including Augustin Farrugia, who later became a senior director at Apple.

entry.title: Apple Music - the lowdown
Taylor Swift: 'I've decided to put 1989 on Apple Music ... and happily so'
entry.summary:
Taylor Swift's album "1989" will be available on Apple's new music service, following the company's reversal of a controversial policy on royalties.

"After the events of this week, I've decided to put 1989 on Apple Music ... and happily so," Swift said on Twitter.

Apple Music charges $9.99 a month for its Spotify-like service, which launches Tuesday.

Apple has promised to pay rights holders at least 71.5 percent of its streaming revenue when customers pay the $9.99 a month subscription.

entry.title: Dr. Dre announces new radio show on Apple Music service
entry.summary:
Apple bought Dre and Jimmy Iovine's Beats by Dre company last year.

Apple's new streaming service features live radio programming, including shows hosted by Zane Lowe, Ebro Darden and Julie Adenuga.

entry.title: Dr. Dre announces new radio show on Apple Music service
entry.summary: Dr. Dre will be busting through your speakers with a new radio show on Apple Music.

entry.title: AC/DC to put music on Spotify, Apple Music
Apple Inc agrees to pay royalties to musicians after Taylor Swift blasts tech giant in open letter
entry.summary: "When I woke up this morning and I saw Taylor's note that she had written, it really solidified that we needed to make a change," said Apple senior vice-president Eddy Cue in an interview with The Associated Press.

entry.title: US court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-book entry
entry.summary:
In a statement, Apple said the ruling did nothing to change the fact that it did not conspire to fix e-book pricing.

In the majority opinion, though, Livingston said it was "startling" that Jacobs would agree Apple intentionally organized a conspiracy among publishers to raise e-book prices and then say the company was entitled to do so because the conspiracy helped it become an e-book retailer.

entry.title: Appeals court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-books case
entry.summary: Two publishers joined Apple's appeal.

entry.title: Apple conspired to fix e-book prices: U.S. appeals court
entry.summary: "While we want to put this behind us, the case is about principles and values," Apple said in a statement.

entry.title: Apple conspired to fix e-book prices: U.S. appeals court
entry.summary: A divided federal appeals court on Tuesday said Apple Inc. orchestrated a conspiracy with five publishers to increase e-book prices, in a victory for the U.S. Justice Department.

entry.title: US court agrees Apple violated antitrust law in e-book entry
entry.summary: The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan ruled 2-to-1 Tuesday that a lower court judge was right to find Apple violated the laws to upset Amazon.com's control of the market.

entry.title: Apple removes Confederate flag games
entry.summary: "We accept Apple's decision and understand that this is a sensitive issue for the American nation."

entry.title: Apple removing games with Confederate flag from App Store
entry.summary: Apple Inc., which is based in Cupertino, California, is the latest company to distance itself from the divisive symbol after the shooting suspect, Dylann Storm Roof, appeared in photos holding the flag.

entry.title: Apple pulls Confederate flag-bearing Civil War games from App Store
entry.summary: Apple issued the following statement: "We have removed apps from the App Store that use the Confederate flag in offensive or mean-spirited ways, which is in violation of our guidelines. We are not removing apps that display the Confederate flag for educational or historical uses."

entry.title: Apple bans Civil War games featuring Confederate flag from App store
entry.summary: The move by Apple prompted some criticism from users online, concerned the ban was ignoring the context in which the symbol was used in some cases and pointing out that World War II games featuring Nazi insignia were still being sold from the store.

entry.title: Apple removes games featuring Confederate flags from App Store
entry.summary:
Apple Inc has removed several civil war games featuring Confederate flags from its App Store, some game developers said.

"Apple has removed our game from AppStore because of usage of the Confederate Flag," Game-Labs, developer of Ultimate General: Gettysburg said.

entry.title: Apple gets to stream Taylor Swift's '1989' album first
entry.summary: She added that "in case you're wondering if this is some exclusive deal like you've seen Apple do with other artists, it's not."

entry.title: Taylor Swift will allow Apple Music to stream '1989' album [Photos]
entry.summary: Swift wrote a critical Tumblr post Sunday about Apple's initial decision to not pay artists during the trial, which begins Tuesday.

entry.title: Taylor Swift: 'I've decided to put 1989 on Apple Music ... and happily so'
entry.summary: Swift sought to assure fans that her decision to put "1989" on Apple Music is not part of an exclusive deal.

entry.title: Taylor Swift will allow Apple Music to stream '1989' album
entry.summary: The singer tweeted Thursday, June 25, that after Apple decided it would pay artists royalties during the free, three-month trial of Apple Music, Swift "decided to put 1989 on Apple Music...and happily so."

entry.title: Taylor Swift will ‘happily’ stream ‘1989’ on Apple Music
entry.summary: "This is simply the first time it's felt right in my gut to stream my album. Thank you, Apple, for your change of heart."

entry.title: Taylor Swift Has Apple Changing Its Tune
entry.summary: But Swift said she would withhold her latest album from the service because Apple wasn't planning to pay artists and labels directly for the use of their music during the free, introductory period.

entry.title: Apple Music in Taylor Swift backdown
entry.summary: "We hear you @taylorswift13 and indie artists. Love, Apple," tweeted executive Eddy @Cue.

entry.title: Taylor Swift pens open letter to Apple about "shocking" policy
entry.summary: But I say to Apple with all due respect, it's not too late to change this policy and change the minds of those in the music industry who will be deeply and gravely affected by this.

entry.title: Taylor Swift writes open letter to Apple Music bosses [Video]
entry.summary: Taylor Swift has written an open letter to Apple Music bosses explaining why she is withholding her album 1989 from their service, telling them "it is unfair to ask anyone to work for nothing".

entry.title: Taylor Swift writes open letter to Apple Music bosses
In open letter, Swift criticizes 'shocking' Apple Music
entry.summary: Writing on her Tumblr page Sunday in a posting titled "To Apple, Love Taylor," Swift said she would withhold her 2014 album "1989" from Apple Music, which launches June 30.

entry.title: In open letter, Swift criticizes 'shocking' Apple Music
entry.summary: Swift said she would withhold her 2014 album "1989" from Apple Music, which launches June 30.

entry.title: In open letter, Swift criticizes 'shocking' Apple Music
entry.summary: In an open letter to Apple, Taylor Swift has criticized the company's new streaming music service for failing to pay artists for a free three-month trial.

entry.title: Taylor Swift Explains Why She Won't Put New Album on Apple Music
entry.summary: "We know how astronomically successful Apple has been, and we know that this incredible company has the money to pay artists, writers and producers for the three-month trial period ... even if it is free for the fans trying it out."

entry.title: Taylor Swift Explains Why '1989' Won't Be on Apple Music in Open Letter
entry.summary: "I'm not sure you know that Apple Music will not be paying writers, producers, or artists for those three months. I find it to be shocking, disappointing, and completely unlike this historically progressive and generous company."

entry.title: Apple Music won?t have Taylor Swift?s ?1989?
Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary:
Washington: Apple is diving deeper into the news business with a new application that could make the US tech giant a key industry player.

"Apple is eager to have news created by human beings and not algorithms - it fits in with the brand statement Apple has been making," said Judd Slivka, a professor of mobile journalism at the University of Missouri.

entry.title: Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary: In a surprising move, Apple has unveiled it will be hiring experienced journalists to manage its news feeds.

entry.title: Apple puts news at core of revamped system
entry.summary:
Apple News, part of the upcoming iOS 9 operating system, aims to be the primary news source for users of the iPhone and iPad.

Customers browse Apple Watches in New York.

Although Apple is likely to use some algorithms to filter stories, the hiring of experienced journalists is a positive step, said Dan Kennedy, a journalism professor at Northeastern University.

entry.title: Taylor Swift says no to Apple Music
entry.summary: Swift's previous albums, though, will be available on Apple Music though.

entry.title: Apple Watch Is Not Yet A Home Run With Users, Survey Shows
entry.summary: Apple is clearly working out these third-party app issues, though.
